section.title: Binomial Coefficients

ul.li: Prove the Binomial Theorem and apply it to find coefficients of terms in expansions.
Describe and prove simple identities involving binomial coefficients possibly in relation to Pascal's Triangle.

section.p: In this section we discuss the quantity \displaystyle\binom{n}{k} in more detail and explore some nice related identities and applications. First, we give a name to the quantity; the reason for the name will be made clear in the main theorem of this section.

statement.p: For k \leq n, the quantities \binom{n}{k} are called binomial coefficients.

section.p: In we saw how the binomial coefficient \displaystyle\binom{n}{k} can be expressed as the sum of two binomial coefficients involving (n-1): \binom{n}{k} = \binom{n-1}{k} + \binom{n-1}{k-1}. This rule is known as Pascal's Formula, after mathematician Blaise Pascal, who formalized many of the results and identities about the binomial coefficients.
generates an intuitive visualization of the binomial coefficients that you may have seen before, widely known as Pascal's Triangle.

aside.p: Pascal was not the first to discover this mathematical object, which was simply called the arithmetical triangle beforehand.

This triangle and its relations to combinatorial problems was known to several other mathematicians: Piṅgala, and several others in India; Chinese mathematicians Jia Xian and Yang Hui; Ahmad Ibn Mun'im, who taught in Marrakesh; Niccolò Tartaglia and Gerolamo Cardano (Italy); Michael Stifel (Germany); and Marin Mersenne, who met and did mathematics with Pascal.

section.p: The reason for the term binomial coefficient is clarified in the next theorem.

statement.p: For k \leq n, the quantity \displaystyle\binom{n}{k} is equal to the coefficient of x^{n-k}y^k in the expansion of (x+y)^n. That is, (x+y)^n = \underbrace{(x+y)(x+y)\cdots(x+y)}_\text{$n$ times} = \displaystyle\sum_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k}x^{n-k}y^k.

proof.p: Each factor in the product (x+y)^n = (x+y)(x+y)\cdots(x+y) contributes either an x or a y in the resulting expansion. We can express each term in the answer as a sequence of n symbols, each either an x or a y; for example, picking x from each (x+y) term gives \underbrace{xx\cdots x}_\text{$n$ times}=x^n.

Hence the number of times x^{n-k}y^k appears in the final expansion is precisely the number of rearrangements of the word \underbrace{x\ x\cdots x}_\text{$n-k$ times}\underbrace{y\ y\cdots y}_\text{$k$ times}, which is exactly equal to \frac{n!}{(n-k)!k!} = \binom{n}{k} by .

statement.p: On the xy-plane, a lattice path is a path that moves from integer point to integer point by taking only steps of length one to the right or upwards. For instance, the following are three different paths to the point (4,2), starting at the origin (0,0):
Each path above can be represented as a sequence of 4 R's and 2 U's:
so the total number of lattice paths from (0,0) to (4,2) is the same as the number of such sequences, which is \binom{6}{4} = \frac{6!}{2! \ 4!}.

section.p: illustrates a useful technique in counting problems: by representing what is being counted (lattice paths) in a different way (sequences of R's and U's), we can uncover the combinatorial structure of these objects, making them easier to count.

statement.p: Count the number of lattice paths ending at (a,b) for integer a,b \geq 0.

solution.p: The number of lattice paths to the point (a,b) is the same as the number of strings of length a+b with a R's and b U's, and this is equal to \dfrac{(a+b)!}{a! \ b!} = \binom{a+b}{a} = \binom{a+b}{b} by .

hint.p: Count the number of lattice paths to (k,n-k).

solution.p: Any lattice path from (0,0) to the point (k,n-k) either passes through the point (k-1,n-k) (and takes one last step to the Right) or the point (k,n-k-1) (and takes one last step Upwards). This is a partition of the set of lattice paths to (k,n-k). We also know from that there are \displaystyle\binom{n}{k} lattice paths to (k,n-k).
Furthermore, by there are \displaystyle\binom{n-1}{k-1} lattice paths to (k-1,n-k) and there are \displaystyle\binom{n-1}{k} lattice paths to (k,n-k-1).
Hence by , we must have \binom{n}{k} = \binom{n-1}{k-1} + \binom{n-1}{k}, as desired.
